name: K.S
comment info:
What do I notice?
- High end SUVS such as the Toyota Sequoia and the Lexus GX are at the top of carbon dioxide emissions and price.
- All fully electric cars have less carbon emissions than gas-powered cars and diesel cars with an average of about 200 grams per mile.
- Hybrid and diesel cars are in the middle for both price and carbon emissions.
- There really is no reason not to choose electric cars other than preference since the price on average is lower than most other types of cars, and the emissions are so low.

What do I wonder?
- I wonder why the hybrid cars still do get emissions higher than some gas-powered.
- I wonder why people still don't choose electric cars even with the low price average and low carbon emissions.

What impact does this have on you and your community?
This graph impacts me and my community because it shows how electric vehicles can be cheap and save the environment, while showing how the other types are over all more expensive for the consumer, and for the environment.

What’s going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
This graph shows that over all, EV's are cheaper in price over time, and helps the environment more than other types of cars. A good headline for this graph would be "EV's: The cars that save the environment and your wallet!"

name: C
comment info:
What do I notice?
-Traditional gas-powered cars always have a higher average 
carbon dioxide emissions per mile than electric cars by at least 50 grams.
-Electric cars have the lowest emissions out of any cars with an average of about 200 grams.
-Hybrid and diesel cars fall in between gas and electric in terms of carbon emissions.
-The most expensive electric cars per month on this list is $150 cheaper than the most expensive diesel, hybrid and gas cars.
-Diesel cars are the most expensive to maintain and fuel on average.

What do I wonder?
-I wonder why more people aren't considering electric cars because of the lower maintenance cost.
-I wonder what the infrastructure is like for charging electric cars, is it always convenient?

What impact does this have on you and your community?
This graph will make the community think about the environment when they make choices related to the type of car that they buy.
Electric cars and hybrid cars are a great long term solution to decreasing carbon emissions because they have a smaller carbon footprint over time.

Headline
Go green, go electric.

name: Lauren Iskander
comment info:
What do you notice?
I notice that electric cars generally cost the least amount of money per month while also creating the least average carbon emissions per mile. Additionally, traditional gas powered cars create the most amount of carbon emissions per mile, but can range in price from most expensive to least expensive per month. This is likely because traditional gas-powered cars are the most abundantly distributed car. Hybrid cars are an average of traditional gas-powered cars and electric cars. They emit less carbon dioxide per mile than gas-powered cars, but the emit more carbon dioxide per mile than electric cars. 

What do you wonder?
From what I have heard from my peers, people refrain from thinking about buying electric cars because they believe they are too expensive. If people knew about the cost efficiency of electric cars, would they be more willing to buy them? 

What impact does this have on you and your community?
The current climate crisis will ultimately effect almost every person in my generation. Many scientists believe that air pollution has caused an increase in cancers, cognitive decline, and depression. Carbon emissions are one of the most significant causes of this air pollution. Thus, the information in this graph should be used to motivate people to buy electric cars instead of traditional gas-powered cars. 

Headline: 
Are electric cars out of your budget? Think again.

name: Paul Coffield
comment info:
I notice that this graph has dots representing different car models. The y axis measures the carbon emissions of the cars while the x axis measures the cost per month. There appears to be a positive correlation between cost and carbon emissions meaning that more expensive cars tend to have higher emissions. The electric cars of course have the lowest carbon emissions while the gas-powered cars have the highest. The Nissan Leaf seems to be one of the cheapest and low-emission vehicles on the graph. The Toyota Sequoia seems to have some of the highest emissions and one of the highest costs out of the vehicles on the graph. I wonder if the vehicles on the top right of the graph are larger (SUVs, vans, etc). I also wonder what the difference between diesel and gas-powered cars is.
My community is heavily sprawled and there is not much public transportation, so cars are a necessity for most people. This graph would be very helpful for people in my community who are looking to buy a car that is environmentally friendly yet affordable. Unfortunately, even electric cars have carbon emissions. Hopefully in the future, cars can become a thing of the past as our society finds more environmentally friendly ways of life. Designing cities and neighborhoods which are pedestrian friendly and not as sprawled is definitely a step in the right direction.
Headline: Cars, Cost, and Carbon

replies.comment info:
Hi Paul

You have done an awesome job at summarizing the graph.  I like how you noted that walking is not really an option in your community.  Is there a good public transportation system?  Do you think public transportation reduces or increases the overall emissions?
